stem: ABG: pH 7.28, PaCO2 60 mm Hg, HCO3 26 mEq/L, PaO2 88 mm Hg. What is the primary disorder?
rationale_correct: Elevated PaCO2 with low pH and minimal HCO3 elevation indicates acute respiratory acidosis.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct because renal compensation has not significantly increased HCO3. | B: Chronic would show higher HCO3. | C: HCO3 not low. | D: No evidence of dual acidosis.
keywords_to_notice: pH low | PaCO2 60 | HCO3 near normal
qa_summary: single best answer: yes; physiology accurate: yes; no repeat: yes

stem: ABG: pH 7.36, PaCO2 62 mm Hg, HCO3 34 mEq/L. What best describes this disorder?
rationale_correct: Near-normal pH with elevated PaCO2 and elevated HCO3 indicates chronic compensation.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Acute would have lower pH. | B: Correct because renal compensation elevated HCO3. | C: PaCO2 elevated. | D: Pattern fits chronic respiratory acidosis.
keywords_to_notice: near normal pH | high CO2 | high HCO3
exam_logic: Normal-ish pH + high CO2 + high HCO3 = chronic.
qa_summary: single best answer: yes; physiology accurate: yes; no repeat: yes

stem: ABG: pH 7.12, PaCO2 70 mm Hg, HCO3 20 mEq/L. What is the best interpretation?
rationale_correct: Severely low pH with elevated CO2 and low HCO3 indicates both respiratory and metabolic acidosis.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: HCO3 too low for pure respiratory acidosis. | B: CO2 too high for pure metabolic acidosis. | C: Correct dual disorder. | D: HCO3 not elevated as expected in chronic.
exam_logic: Opposing CO2 and HCO3 directions signal mixed disorder.
qa_summary: single best answer: yes; physiology accurate: yes; no repeat: yes

stem: ABG: pH 7.50, PaCO2 30 mm Hg, HCO3 23 mEq/L. What is the primary disturbance?
rationale_correct: High pH with low PaCO2 and minimal HCO3 change indicates acute respiratory alkalosis.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: HCO3 not elevated. | B: Correct pattern. | C: Chronic would show lower HCO3. | D: No dual alkalosis evidence.
keywords_to_notice: pH high | CO2 low | HCO3 normal
qa_summary: single best answer: yes; physiology accurate: yes; no repeat: yes

stem: ABG: pH 7.44, PaCO2 30 mm Hg, HCO3 19 mEq/L. What is the best interpretation?
rationale_correct: Near-normal pH with low PaCO2 and reduced HCO3 indicates chronic respiratory alkalosis with renal compensation.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Acute would have near-normal HCO3. | B: Correct compensated pattern. | C: pH not acidemic. | D: Compensation explains pattern.
keywords_to_notice: near normal pH | low CO2 | low HCO3
exam_logic: Opposite shift in HCO3 suggests chronic compensation.
qa_summary: single best answer: yes; physiology accurate: yes; no repeat: yes

stem: ABG: pH 7.30, PaCO2 30 mm Hg, HCO3 15 mEq/L. What is the primary disorder?
option_c: Mixed metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis
rationale_correct: Low HCO3 with low pH indicates metabolic acidosis; low CO2 reflects compensatory hyperventilation.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct compensation pattern. | B: HCO3 too low for primary respiratory alkalosis. | C: CO2 change matches compensation. | D: CO2 not elevated.
keywords_to_notice: low HCO3 | low CO2 | pH low
exam_logic: Match primary change with pH direction.
qa_summary: single best answer: yes; physiology accurate: yes; no repeat: yes

stem: ABG: pH 7.48, PaCO2 48 mm Hg, HCO3 34 mEq/L. What is the primary disorder?
rationale_correct: Elevated HCO3 with alkalemia indicates metabolic alkalosis; elevated CO2 reflects compensatory hypoventilation.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct. | B: HCO3 elevation suggests metabolic origin. | C: pH not acidemic. | D: CO2 elevated not low.
keywords_to_notice: high HCO3 | high CO2 | pH high
qa_summary: single best answer: yes; physiology accurate: yes; no repeat: yes

stem: A ventilated patient has ABG: pH 7.55, PaCO2 25 mm Hg. Which ventilator adjustment is most appropriate?
rationale_correct: Low PaCO2 with alkalemia indicates overventilation; decreasing rate reduces minute ventilation.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Would worsen alkalosis. | B: Correct because it reduces CO2 elimination. | C: Would further reduce CO2. | D: Oxygenation not primary issue.
exam_logic: Control minute ventilation to correct CO2.
qa_summary: single best answer: yes; physiology accurate: yes; no repeat: yes

stem: ABG: pH 7.25, PaCO2 78 mm Hg, HCO3 36 mEq/L. What best describes this disorder?
rationale_correct: Elevated HCO3 suggests chronic retention, but low pH indicates acute worsening on top of chronic baseline.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: pH too low for fully compensated chronic. | B: HCO3 too high for purely acute. | C: Correct mixed timing interpretation. | D: CO2 elevated, not metabolic origin.
keywords_to_notice: high CO2 | high HCO3 | low pH
common_trap: Missing acute deterioration on chronic pattern.
exam_logic: Compensation present but insufficient = acute on chronic.
qa_summary: single best answer: yes; physiology accurate: yes; no repeat: yes

sub_concept: Uncompensated metabolic acidosis with inadequate ventilation
stem: ABG: pH 7.18, PaCO2 50 mm Hg, HCO3 18 mEq/L. What is the best interpretation?
option_b: Metabolic acidosis with inadequate ventilatory compensation
rationale_correct: Metabolic acidosis should cause low CO2 as compensation; elevated CO2 indicates inadequate ventilation.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: CO2 should be low if compensation appropriate. | B: Correct because ventilation is failing to compensate. | C: HCO3 low indicates metabolic origin. | D: HCO3 not elevated.
exam_logic: If CO2 not appropriately low, ventilation inadequate.
qa_summary: single best answer: yes; physiology accurate: yes; no repeat: yes
